On a recent test crawl, we stepped on an interesting, unintentional
crawler trap related to soft 404s, relative URLs, and the implicit
typing of certain fetches.

If you view the site...

  http://www.af.mil:80/photos/art_current.shtml/

...you'll see a number of images don't load. However, as they are
relative URLs, their bad paths are being passed to the .shtml as
extra path-info, in a fetch like:

  http://www.af.mil/photos/art_current.shtml/images/afg_030325_002-001.jpg

The .shtml ignores the path info, returns its normal HTML page (same
as before), but now those bad paths, relative to the enclosing 
bad path, are of the form:

  http://www.af.mil/photos/art_current.shtml/images/images/afg_030325_002-001.jpg

...and so on, and so on.

So essentially the .shtml script is making the entire universe
of path-extensions past ...shtml/ into soft 404s -- even though the 
server as a whole doesn't do soft 404s.  (Try http://www.af.mil/blah )

Some implications:
 - Soft 404 detection might be worth triggering after
   certain '/'-terminated paths; in particular after 
   some large number X of '/'s are seen in a single URL

 - Any duplicate-detection process, which generally
   *shouldn't* preclude relative URLs from being processed
   as if they were new, might want to trigger the 
   soft-404 check or otherwise detect certain URL-patterns
   to see if a pathological recursion is occuring

 - If URLs are labelled as to the *context* in which
   they were discovered, that could assist in soft-404
   and other pathological condition detection. For 
   example, it is only when trying to fetch an embedded
   image, and getting HTML instead, that teh problem
   relative recursive URLs are encountered.

- Gordon
